abstract: Apple argues that unlocking your iPhone violates a provision of copyright law that imposes fines and sometimes even up to five years of jail time.
snippet: Apple argues that unlocking your iPhone violates a provision of copyright law that imposes fines and sometimes even up to five years of jail time.
lead_paragraph: There is something deeply exasperating about the debate, spotlighted Thursday, about whether unlocking an iPhone violates Apple’s copyright on the cellphone’s software. There’s a real issue at stake, but it isn’t fundamentally about copyrights.

headline.main: Could You Go to Jail for Jailbreaking Your iPhone?
